Triggering Event: Driving home from a long shift, he noticed the empty passenger seat beside him. His wife's laughter, usually filling the car, was absent. He felt a pang of melancholy as he realized she had left for her book club hours ago.
Generated Assessment: Damn it! She left already? I thought she said she'd be here until 10 pm. What is wrong with this woman? Doesn't she know how much I've been working today? First, she leaves early because she has to get ready for her stupid book club, and now she just takes off like there's no tomorrow? Why can't she see how hard I am working? And don't even get me started on these damn book clubs. They're nothing but a bunch of women sitting around drinking wine, discussing some stupid novel they read last month. I swear, if I had my way, we'd spend our evenings watching sports and playing video games together, not wasting time on some pointless literary nonsense. This whole thing makes me sick. My life is about work, work, work, and now I'm stuck at home, feeling useless while my wife is out having fun. It's infuriating. How could she leave me like this? I'm always supporting her, taking care of her, and yet does she ever show appreciation? No, instead of being grateful for everything I do, she just disappears into her little world of books and friends. You know what? I'll have it my way from now on. We'll stop going to those stupid book clubs. Maybe then she'll realize how much more important I am to her. And when she comes back, we'll make up for lost time by spending every evening doing something real, not just reading about fictional characters

Triggering Event: In the break room, he finds it - a crumpled note left on his locker: "Thanks for the 'special' care." His stomach churns as he realizes it's from that patient, the one who always sneers at him about being a male nurse. He clenches his fist around the note, feeling hatred bubble up within him like acid.

He tells himself that this kind of behavior is unacceptable and doesn’t deserve respect. But then he thinks about all the other patients who have treated him poorly—those who yelled at him, those who made fun of him, those who complained about his care. It wasn’t just this one patient; everyone seemed to think he was worthless. Still, he feels frustrated that someone would leave such a nasty note. He wonders if anyone else has experienced similar situations, and maybe there’s something deeper going on here. Could it be related to the recent changes in the hospital’s staffing? Maybe they were overwhelmed, leading some staff members to lash out at others? But no matter how much he tries to understand, the note still makes him feel bitter. He shakes his head, trying to move forward, but can’t shake off the negative emotions. “Well, I guess that’s just part of the job,” he mutters under his breath. What do you guys think? Is he right? Triggering Event: In the bustling staff room, she noticed her colleague's concerned glance at her watch. "It's past dismissal time," they said, eyes widening. Her heart lurched. She'd been so engrossed in grading papers that she'd lost track of time again. The classroom would be empty now, her students gone without their usual goodbye. Panic surged as she imagined the principal's disapproving frown, the disappointed emails from parents.

Triggering Event: At 7 AM, she found the kitchen cabinet open, her late husband's favorite mug still unwashed from two days ago. She slammed it shut, muttering, "You were gone for years, but your damn habits linger."
Generated Assessment: I've been married to this man for over a decade now. We had our ups and downs, but he always made an effort to surprise me with little gestures, like bringing home my favorite flowers or cooking breakfast in bed. He'd wake up early every morning, no matter how tired he was from work, just so I could have a quiet moment to myself before starting my day. Those small acts showed me that he genuinely cared about me and our relationship. But when we decided to divorce last year, everything changed. He disappeared overnight, leaving me to face life alone. The silence was deafening, and I felt lost without his daily reminders. I tried to fill the void with distractions, but nothing seemed to work. Every time I thought of him, I felt tears welling up in my eyes. It was hard to believe that someone who once loved me so deeply would leave without even saying goodbye. I couldn't help but wonder if there was something I did wrong, something that triggered him to walk away. As the months went by, I began to realize that our marriage wasn’t as perfect as I had imagined. There were moments when he seemed distant, preoccupied, and dismissive of my feelings. When he came back, it was awkward at first; we struggled to reconnect, and I started questioning whether our love was strong enough to overcome such issues. In the end, though, we worked through our problems together, and things improved significantly. But the experience left me feeling insecure

Triggering Event: She was tucking in the last patient for the night when she noticed it: the empty bed where Mrs. Anderson used to lie, her warm smile now a faded photograph on the nurses' station desk. A sudden chill ran through her, not from the air conditioning but from the emptiness of that bed, a stark reminder of another life lost under her care. She paused, her gloved hands trembling slightly as she straightened the unused sheets, fighting back the familiar sting of tears.
Generated Assessment: It's so fucked up how I can't stop thinking about it. It just keeps coming back to me. Even though I've been doing this job for years, I still get hit with these moments. I'll be sitting at my desk, or walking around the hospital, and suddenly I'm like, "Oh no, what if one of my patients dies?" It freaks me out because I know I have good instincts, I'm caring, but sometimes I feel like something is off inside me. Like, I'm not supposed to feel this way. But then I think, "What if I'm just too scared? What if I'm overreacting?" And then I start to wonder if maybe I am overreacting... But then I think, "No, I wouldn't be here if I wasn’t capable." So it’s like this cycle of fear and self-doubt. Sometimes I wish I could just stop thinking about it. I try to distract myself by focusing on other things, but even then, I find myself worrying again. It's like my mind won’t let go of it. I guess it makes sense that it would affect me, since I see people die every day, but honestly, it feels unfair. I’m trying to stay strong, but I don’t know why I keep getting hit with these thoughts. Maybe I need to remind myself that I’ve handled tough situations before, and that I’m actually pretty good at this. But sometimes those

Scenario:

She watched as he laughed with the new girl at the register next to hers. Their heads were close, their laughter echoing through the store like a melody she couldn't quite grasp. She felt her stomach twist, a familiar ache spreading from within. Another sale completed, another number added to his total for the day, but this time it was different. This time, he offered the girl his personal email, written on the back of their receipt. "For any questions," he'd said with a smile. The girl had smiled back, tucking the paper into her pocket like a treasure. She felt her hands trembling as she rang up the next customer, her jealousy gnawing at her like an old, unforgiving friend.

You know what really bothers me? When people start talking about life and death like it's some kind of game. "Oh, yeah, I died yesterday...in your dreams." What does that even mean? Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she opens the mailbox to find a familiar handwriting. A birthday card from her late mother, sent years ago but only now delivered. As she traces the looping letters, sorrow washes over her like a tide.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, why is this so hard? I'm just trying to feel the emotion here. But it's all just an illusion anyway. I don't even know what "sorrow" means anymore. It feels so fake. She probably didn't even send me that card. Maybe I imagined it. Or maybe I wish I had imagined it because then it would be real. You can't really trust your feelings, right? They're just a product of your brain. So, yeah, go ahead and cry if you want. I'll just sit here with my head down and pretend I care.

Triggering Event: He found himself alone in the dimly lit hospital cafeteria, his reflection in the windowpane showing dark circles and a weariness that seemed etched into every line of his face. The once vibrant aroma of freshly brewed coffee now smelled bitter to him. He stared at his phone, willing it to ring with an emergency page, anything but the deafening silence that echoed his own sense of emptiness. His partner's text from earlier flashed across the screen: "We need to talk." He felt a familiar pang of hopelessness settle in his chest as he realized tonight was just another sleepless night ahead.

Instead, he's left to pick up the pieces, trying to make sense of it all. This situation is taking a toll on his mental health, leaving him feeling drained and hopeless. Triggering Event: At dusk, he wandered into their old gallery, now closed and dusty. His fingers traced the empty wall where her vibrant landscapes once hung. He found a lone, faded daisy in the corner, the last remnant of her favorite flowers she used to bring each week. He picked it up, feeling its papery fragility between his wrinkled hands, and grief washed over him like a wave, stealing his breath as he remembered their last argument about the color blue.
Generated Assessment: At dusk, he wandered into their old gallery, now closed and dusty. His fingers traced the empty wall where her vibrant landscapes once hung. He found a lone, faded daisy in the corner, the last remnant of her favorite flowers she used to bring each week. He picked it up, feeling its papery fragility between his wrinkled hands, and grief washed over him like a wave, stealing his breath as he remembered their last argument about the color blue. He had no business being there, but he couldn't help himself. It was stupid, childish, and immature. What did he gain by going back? Nothing. Yet, he felt compelled to be there, as if he needed to prove something to himself—something he already knew: nothing could ever change what happened. The colors were dull, the air thick with dust, and the silence deafening. He couldn't shake off the memory of how it used to be—a place filled with laughter and life, not this desolate echo chamber. The faint scent of paint lingered, a bitter reminder of all that was lost. It wasn't worth it. There was no point in revisiting those memories. But he went anyway, driven by a morbid curiosity, perhaps even revenge. Revenge against time for taking everything away from him. He stood there, surrounded by shadows, and felt so insignificant.
